an5.140:4.1: “Mendicants, a royal bull elephant with five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5.140:4.3: A royal bull elephant listens, destroys, protects, endures, and goes fast.
an5.140:5.1: And how does a royal bull elephant listen?
an5.140:5.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant pays attention, focuses, directs its whole mind, and listens well to whatever task the elephant trainer has it do,
an5.140:5.3: whether or not it’s done it before.
an5.140:5.5: That’s how a royal bull elephant listens.
an5.140:6.1: And how does a royal bull elephant destroy?
an5.140:6.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle destroys elephants with their riders, horses with their riders, chariots and charioteers, and foot soldiers.
an5.140:6.3: That’s how a royal bull elephant destroys.
an5.140:7.1: And how does a royal bull elephant protect?
an5.140:7.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle protects its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its fore-feet and hind-feet, and its head, ears, tusks, trunk, tail, and rider.
an5.140:7.3: That’s how a royal bull elephant protects.
an5.140:8.1: And how does a royal bull elephant endure?
an5.140:8.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant in battle endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and cymbals.
an5.140:8.3: That’s how a royal bull elephant endures.
an5.140:9.1: And how does a royal bull elephant go fast?
an5.140:9.2: It’s when a royal bull elephant swiftly goes in whatever direction the elephant trainer sends it,
an5.140:9.3: whether or not it’s been there before.
an5.140:9.5: That’s how a royal bull elephant goes fast.
an5.140:10.1: A royal bull elephant with these five factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is considered a factor of kingship.
an5.140:11.1: In the same way, a mendicant with five qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a teacher’s offering, worthy of veneration with folded palms, and is a supreme field of merit for the world.
an5.140:11.3: A mendicant listens, destroys, protects, endures, and goes fast.
an5.140:12.1: And how does a mendicant listen?
an5.140:12.2: It’s when a mendicant pays attention, focuses, concentrates, and listens well when the teaching and training announced by a Realized One is being taught.
an5.140:13.1: And how does a mendicant destroy?
an5.140:13.2: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t tolerate a sensual thought that’s arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, destroys it, eliminates it, and exterminates it.
an5.140:13.3: They don’t tolerate a malicious thought … They don’t tolerate a harmful thought … They don’t tolerate any bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, destroy them, eliminate them, and exterminate them.
an5.140:14.1: And how does a mendicant protect?
an5.140:14.2: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
an5.140:14.3: If the faculty of sight was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint,
an5.140:14.6: Hearing a sound with the ears … Smelling an odor with the nose … Tasting a flavor with the tongue … Feeling a touch with the body … Knowing a phenomena with the mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
an5.140:14.7: If the faculty of mind was left unrestrained, bad unwholesome qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint,
an5.140:15.1: And how does a mendicant endure?
an5.140:15.2: It’s when a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles;
an5.140:15.3: rude and unwelcome criticism; and puts up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
an5.140:16.1: And how does a mendicant go fast?
an5.140:16.2: It’s when a mendicant swiftly goes in the direction they’ve never gone before in all this long time; that is, the stilling of all conditions, the letting go of all attachments, the ending of craving, fading away, cessation, extinguishment.
an5.140:16.3: That’s how a mendicant goes fast.
an5.140:17.1: A mendicant with these five factors … is a supreme field of merit for the world.”
